subject: Re: What if we dont name any methods as testXXXX() in junits. What it will run-i am suppossing that compilation will succeed-what will happen at runTime?
msgSnippet: ... Try it. _ _ _ Typically what will happen is that the TestSuite constructor, which takes your TestCase class (as a java.lang.Class) will realize that there
messageBody:
--- Ashutosh Sharma <ashutosh.sharma@o...> wrote:
> What if we dont name any methods as testXXXX() in junits.
> What it will run-i am suppossing that compilation will
> succeed-what will happen at runTime?

Try it.

_ _ _


Typically what will happen is that the TestSuite constructor, which
takes your TestCase class (as a java.lang.Class) will realize that
there are no suitable test methods, so it will append an anonymous
inner "warning" class (extending TestCase) that does nothing but fail
with a warning "No tests found in your.class.Name". It will also
warn you if you have 'void testXXXX()' methods that are not public.

If this is not what you want...

Well, if you want to have TestCase classes with no test methods,
because they're all disabled for example, then add an artifical test
method that does nothing but successfully return. This will prevent
JUnit from complaining. (This is a bad thing to do, but I've been
known to do it, from time to time.)

If you want to use some other naming standard for test methods (and
lord knows why you would want to do that), declare a 'public static
Test suite()' method in your TestCase, and build your own TestSuite.
Search for "Parameterized Test Case" for suggestions.
